intro: Aceras hircinum var. divergens, commonly known as the Persian bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, blue or violet flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils and thrives in full sun to partial shade. Its leaves are lance-shaped and have a hairy texture, while its stems are upright and branched. It is valued for its ornamental appeal and is sometimes cultivated in gardens for its vibrant floral display.
